Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		If John were to take the highway south, he would end up in Mexico. Choices: a,e: E: Mexico. a,e: d,b: oklahoma. e,a: B: developed land. a,e: c,d: united states. e,a: d: desert.<n><n>### Input : I had a bad experience in the gym. What was so terrible? Choices:  W: You were there.  a: There was something. W: I didn't get a day pass. a: I didn't lift the weights up.  b: I broke the glass at the gym.  c: There were too many people.  d: I was injured.  e: I couldn't buy a towel.<n>AoW: Write a function that properly completes the above request.

Some the electronic devices that are commonly used in homes are computers, smartphones, telephone, radios, televisions and lighting among others. Electrical devices have made work easy and efficient. Work will continue to be made easy with the technological advancement. Electrical device helps to reduce work, therefore, electricity is required in our daily lives. Some of the things required to be used with the electrical devices are the electronics components.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:A school is most likely to be located in what sort of zone? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: community C: building D: prague E: every city<n><n>### Response:		<n>It would be most likely to be located inside of the city itself.<n><n>### Inputs and outputs:<n><n>A computer can output its input into its output.  Inputs  can also become inputs of other computers as long as the input does not become overloaded.  Inputs are not necessarily outputs; a computer may have outputs without having any inputs.<n><n>### Output<n>An output is a response to an input.<n><n>### Intricate vs elaborate<n>Intricate and elaborate have the same meaning.<n><n>### The machine was very intricately designed.<n>In the above sentence, the machine is obviously the intricate part, but this is a subject, not a predicate.  Therefore, the sentence is incorrect.<n><n>To re-write the sentence to have a predicate, I would say:<n>Machine was<n><n>### very<n>This is an adverb that describes the level of intensity of something.<n><n>### was<n>"Was" is the past tense of "is" It signifies that something happened in the past.<n><n>### very is adverb and intensifies very by adding an intensification of an adjective<n>very intricate<n>very complicated<n><n>### is a past tense<n><n>### intricate<n>Intricate can describe a physical thing such as a machine (an intricate mechanism), or can it can describe something, such as a design (an intricate design.)<n><n>### intricately designed<n>This word is redundant; the sentence already states that the machine was intricate.  I would rewrite it so that the sentence says:<n>Machine was intricate.<n><n>### A: burn hot<n>Burn is a transitive verb.<n><n>### hot<n>"Hot" is an adjective. It's modifying "burn."  Therefore, is correct because it is an adjective that modifies the verb.<n><n>## Task:<n>In the box below, use the information to answer the question.<n><n>What is the adverb in the sentence?<n><n>a) in the wrong direction<n><n>b) to an overabundance<n><n>c) to the wrong location<n><n>d) in the right direction<n><n>e) in the wrong manner<n><n>f) to the correct place<n><n>g) in a way that was not satisfactory to the individual<n><n>h) in the wrong manner that was not appropriate for the outcome

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:What is a child likely to do while going to play? Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: happiness D: being entertained E: walk slowly<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>[Please click here to view the instruction that describes the task.](./MultipleChoice.md)<n><n>### Input<n>In the above multiple choice question, the reader might choose any of the above. Let‚Äôs see the instructions in the above question:<n><n>Where do you get petrol?, Where might a television used At night be?, Where might a child likely to do?<n><n>There are several multiple choice questions that can be prepared very easily.<n><n>### Solution<n>```Rubymine<n>Ruby on rails<n><n>class MultipleChoice<n>  def initialize(question,choice)<n>    @question=question<n>    @choice=choice<n>  end<n><n>  def answer<n>    if @question==@choice<n>      "Great, that's the answer"<n>    else<n>      "not correct"<n>    end<n>  end<n>end<n>```<n><n><n>### Output example(with ruby console)<n><n>```ruby<n>>> MultiChoice.new("Where do you get petroleum?",'D')<n>=> "Great, that‚Äôs the answer"<n>>> MultiChoice.answer("Where do you get oil")<n>=> not correct<n><n>```<n><n>### Output Example(with ruby files)<n><n>```ruby  <n>class MultipleChoice<n>    def initialize(question, choice)<n>       @question = question<n>       @choice = choice<n>      <n>    end  <n>  <n>    def answer<n>       if @question == @choice<n>          "Great, that is the answer"<n>       else<n>          "You guessed it wrong"<n>       end<n>  <n>    end  <n>end  <n><n>MultipleChoice.answer("Where can you get petrol?")<n><n>### Output<n>>  You guessed it wrong<n>```<n>### Output<n>![output_12-01-18_172119.png](/images/output_12-1-18_22_19.png)<n><n>### Output <n><n>![output15-01-172130.png](/images/multiple_choice/output15-1-18.png)<n><n>

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast with a large family leads to a pile of what in the sink? Choices:  A: fullness B: underwear C: bad breath D: better day E: dirty dishes<n><n>### Response:		The response should be an appropriate verb phrase that uses the appropriate word.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A: A B: B C: C D: D E: E<n><n>### Instrutions:<n>The number of tasks are determined by counting instructions of the format below, as well as their number of letters.<n><n>> Instructions: Write a sentence that correctly inserts the appropriate nouns in the blanks.<n><n>> Instruction:A sentence with more than one instruction is written like the one above.<n><n>> Instrumentation: Instructions will always follow these steps. Example: A: A B: B<n><n>Response: The number of tasks are determined when there are letters in the instruction. There are six letters of letters in the instruction above, so six tasks will have to be written.<n><n>### Output:<n>Outputs are written in sentences, where each output consists of the number of instructions and words, as well as the number of words. Example: Instructions: write a sentence that correctly inserds the _______?<n><n><n>### Results:<n>The result are written as tables, where the first column is the variable. In this instance, the variable is the input to the task, the second column is the correct word, and the third column is the response that was provided.<n><n>Output:Instructions:write a sentence that correctly insers the _______?

Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  a) b) c) d) e) f) g) h)<n><n>### Response should either be burn hot or fuel tank or car, as long as the correct one is selected.<n><n>### A sentence should be rewritten for the following.<n><n>1. Choices are either their coats are different, or they are different mammals.<n><n>### When do babies not have long ears? Choices are either the ears don't grow until they are older, or ears are already short.<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a computer other than a desk? Choices:  A: apartment B: table C: school D: office E: house<n><n>### Response:		A:<n><n>### Input:-1<n><n><img src="images/image.jpg" alt="Your image" width = 25em height = 25em><n><n>### Input:/home/computer/users<n><n><img src = "images/home.png" alt = "Home" width = 20 em height = 20 em><n><n>### Response:-1<n><n><li>A:box</li><n><n>```python<n>from pathlib import Path<n><n>path = Path("home/computer")<n>print(f"Input:/home/computer/{str(list(path.glob('users/*')))}")<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:What would happen to you if you are not good at playing violin? Choices:  A: happiness B: relaxation C: create music D: sadness E: loud noises<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n><ul><n><li>Complete the instruction, follow up using if else and then else</li><n><li>After each question, give a clear sentence with the answer and a full explanation.<n></li><n><ol><n>{{% assign answer = "False" %}}<n>### Instruction answer :<n>    {{% raw %}}<pre>Let's see how a conditional works!<n><n>If (statement):<n><n>    Let's test if the dog is happy?<n><n>    answer :{{% assignment not_nil = answer %}}<n><n>if (the dog is happy):<n>    answer: I'm happy<n>else (Answer: I'm not happy)<n><n>If (Statement):<n>Let's test if the student is in the class?<n><n>    {{% raw%}}<n>        answer:<n>    {{% /raw%}}<n><n>if (The student is in the class):<n>    answer:<n>    I'm happy<n>    else (Answer: I'am not happy )<n><n>{{% assignment not_null = answer %}}<n>I'm happy<n><n>{{% assignment assignment - 2 - "is true:"%}}<n>I'am not happy ;<n>{{% raw %}}<n>    {{% raw  %}}<n><n>{{% assignment show - assignment %}}<n>if: Is true<n><n>{{% assignment test - assignment %}}<n>test:<n>I'm happy!<n>{{% end raw %}}<n>{{% assignment else - assignment %}}<n>else (I'am not happy ) :<n>{{% end raw -5 %}}<n></pre><n><ol>{{% assign count 1 %}}<n><li>The dog is happy</li><li>The student is in the  class  </li><n></ol><n>{{% raw %}}(statement : is not true)<n><ol>{{< /raw >><n><li>The student  is in the  class </li>{{% raw %}}(Statement : is not true)</li><li>I'am not happy.</li><n>{{% raw "}}{{/raw %}}<n>{{% raw %}}}<n></pre><n><n></ul><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Where might a human sit for extended periods over a bowl of water? Choices:  A: bathroom B: solar system C: coffee shop D: space shuttle E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>  | 1.B<n>  | 2.C<n>  | 3.B<n>  |<n><n>### Instructions for response<n><n>Write a program that reads data from standard input and answers the question.<n><n>- The first line contains an integer \`N\`, the number of test cases, between 1 \`N\` \`\` 100.<n>- Each of the rest input lines contain a string consisting of one word or multiple words, split by white spaces.<n>- After all tests, output the responses for each test cases in a line, separated by a newline. Each response contains a string which has length equal to 1 for each possible answer, that is, if the current answer is A, the size of the answer is 1, otherwise, it is 0.<n><n>#### Sample Input:<n>```<n>5<n>The machine was very intricate.<n>Where do you get petrol.<n>Where might a television used at.<n>Where can you get coffee.<n>Where might a human sit.<n>```<n><n>#### Sample Outout<n>```<n>5<n>1<n>1<n>1<n>0<n>0<n>```<n>##### Explanation:<n>There are 4 questions in total, and the last line has only 1 response because it has the correct answer.<n><n>### Source:<n>https://www.hackerrank.com/challenges/easy-string-operation<n><n>### Hints<n>- You can use a two dimensional array to store your answer table and use if else to check and return the answer.<n>- You can use the len() function to get the length of a string.<n><n>

Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choice: A: box<n>2. Option: E: implements<n>3. Choice: D: class<n>4. Choice: C: university<n>5. Choice: E: gas station(s)<n>6. Option: D: bill<n>7. Choice: E<n>8. Choice: D<n>9. Choice: A<n>10. Choices:  A: company B: airport C: wall D: computer network E: love<n><n>### Response:		<n><n> - E: computer network<n> - A: company<n> - C: the walls of a building<n> - D: a bus station, airport, etc.<n><n> - A: the computer<n> - B: where James is connected with, i.e. computer to internet<n> - C: how James connected with anything<n> - D: the phone network<n>

(This sentence is a noun phrase.) How would you say it? (This is a verb phrase.) <n><n>What is the opposite for this phrase?<n><n># Task 19: The following sentence means to inform you that the answer will be here soon.<n><n># Task 20:<n>The following sentence means that the first phrase describes the second phrase, but that the second phrase describes the first phrase.<n><n><n>What can be said about the second phrase? (The following sentence is a gerund phrase.) What is the correct answer? (The following phrase is a gerund phrase. This is also a relative clause.) 1)  This is not an appropriate answer for this sentence. (The following sentence is not a question.) 2) This is an appropriate question for this sentence. (This sentence is not a question or an answer. 3) I do not know what to call it, but I find it confusing. (The following sentence describes several things.) How should it be described? (This is a gerund phrase that describes several different things.) # Task 21

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Why would someone confess to committing murder? Choices:  A: guilty conscience B: fear C: go free D: problems E: find god<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is C go free.<n><n><n>### Feedback:<n>```<n>The following are the options that you need to select from.<n>1. A: burn hot<n>2. B: fuel tank<n>3. C: burn hot<n>4. D: car<n>5. E: gas station<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Select the right choice to complete the sentences.<n><n>### Explanation:The first thing you notice about this question is that it is a short response. There are five sentences, so you have a lot of information to read and consider. The first sentence is quite specific: we are told that the information was expensive. This is an indication that something unique is happening in the answer and, if you read to the end of this sentence, you'll find out.<n><n>### The key to this question is in the penultimate word of sentence 3. You should also consider what the preceding sentence says: 'Where might a television used at Night be?' and look for the phrase 'been used'. This information helps us to make a key connection between the first four statements and the final sentence. <n><n>### Consider the first four statements carefully. You are told what the answer is and, in doing so, you can deduce one piece of information that we needed earlier. Each statement gives us a clue to find the missing word. Let's look each statement individually:<n><n>### Input 1: We are told that the machine was very intricate - intricate means complicated. This was no simple box.<n><n>### Input2: The machine was quite an apparatus. Apparatus has a technical connotation and so this wasn't an everyday box.<n><n>## #3: Now there's a really important clue. The machine was a *implement*. Think hard about where an implement was more likely to be seen - in a home or in the woods. And, finally:<n>## #4: We know where we are now. The machine was indeed *a complex system *. We can draw a line from the end of sentence 4 and the final statement.<n><n>### So, sentence 5 might begin in a way that suggests a machine was confiscated for illegal activity. The phrase, 'Go Free', suggests just that. Confessing to something you've done wrong is the only way a *murderer could be let free

Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Why might someone want to be buying beer? It always gave feel good about yourself.<n><n>### Explanation1:<n>The machine was very intricate. A: burn hot<n>B: fuel tank<n>C: burn hot<n>D: car<n>E: gas station<n><n>The petrol is kept in the car. Who likes to go to the zoo?<n>- What do you like to do on the weekend?<n>2. What is the capital city of the US?<n>- Why are you the most beautiful.<n>3. What is the speed limit in miles per hour?<n>- How many questions are there?<n>4. Which is the smallest in size?<n>- How many years do you have?<n>5. What is the largest in size?<n>- Which is the least busy road?<n>Answer: 2. What is the speed of the US in miles per hour? Is not a question and answer, because the speed of the US is a number and it can not be answer like a question.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer was B: classroom.<n><n>### Why:<n><n>- the pencils were needed for school.<n><n>### Input Description: The student needed to get some new pencil <n>- 'to' is not used before 'go' ('got') or 'need' ('needed') and 'pencil' is a countable noun.<n> - The verb 'go' requires a subject.<n> - The subject is a person or things.<n> - 'classroom' (noun) is a person or thing<n> - The verb 'classroom' is 'to' not 'at' a school 'classroom'.<n> - 'goes' takes an's' at the end.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>In the sentence, the student needs to  get some new  pencils.<n><n>In the question, the student needs to get some new pennies where did he go.<n><n>The preposition is 'did' not 'do'.<n><n>Explanation:<n>'where' is the direct object (direct object of the verb 'got').<n><n>Explanation 2:<n>'gone' is the past participle form of 'go'.<n><n>Explanations:<n><n>### Other Correct Questions:<n><n>- He needs to get a new pen. -> He needs to get some new pens.<n><n>He needs to get new pencils at the store. <n><n>- Where was the pencils being sold?<n><n>- He needs a new pencil. -> He needs some new pencils.<n>- At the store he got some new pencils.'

Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:The new play was the go to performance of the year, all the crowds would stand and what? Choices:  A: admiration B: applaud C: make reservations D: experience E: sleep<n><n>### Response:		<n>The new play was the *go to* performance of the year, that all the crowds would *stand* and *admire*.<n>#### **[Solution 1]**<n>- _The new play was the_<n>- Go to = be used or visited<n>- Admire = have feelings of admiration or approval towards somebody/something<n>- _all the crowds_<n>- _would stand and_<n>- Stand = to be in a vertical position from a sitting or lying position<n>- Admire =><n>#### **[Solutions 2]**<n>- _would_<n>```<n>*The new play was the*<n>```<n>- [Verb] => stand<n>```<n>*all the crowds,*<n>```<n>In the sentence "all the crowds...", this indicates a list of nouns after the comma (nouns used to refer to something).<n>```<n>*admire* / would<n>```<n>- [Adjective] => admire<n>```<n>*somebody/something*<n>```<n>In this context, "somebody" and "something" are interchangeable in meaning. To answer<n>the question, "Where is the new play being admired?"<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: You must ask permission to get a permit. Choices: A:  B:  C: D: E: F: G: H:  I:  J: K: L:  M: N:  O: Q: P Q: R<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A: You must ask _____ to get a permit.<n>Answer: F: permission<n><n>### Input : A: Who do _____ you know in the school? Choices: B:  C:  D: E: F G: H: I:  J:K: L:  M : N:  O: P Q R: <n><n>### Demossration:<n>Input : A:  Who do you know in the school, Q: <n>Answer: M : <n><n>### Input/Demos<n>#### **[Solu]**<n>```C: <n>```<n>- _you know_ => who<n>-  _in the school_ => in <n><n>### Demo/Input<n>#### **[Sol]**<n>```H:<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Where could a printer be used by thousands of people? Choices:  A: school B: home office C: people store D: print shop E: newspaper office<n><n>### Response:		<n>Between 1919 and 1976, a gas tax was imposed on fuel in North America. After its introduction in Canada, the Canadian government began to promote natural gas for use in the provinces because it was cheaper than gasoline and a lot cleaner. Natural gas is a byproduct of the oil industry and is very clean for fuel.<n><n>The tax incentive made a huge difference. People were much more willing to use a more expensive fuel in the 1970s compared to the present-day with the $1.30 per litre price tag in gasoline, as the cost of the fuel is so high. The same fuel will cost $1.00 per litre, which is 50 per cent less than gasoline. There are over 1,150,000 homes in Ontario alone that use natural gas as their primary energy source, and this number continues to grow.<n><n>Fuel pump stations are more prevalent in Ontario than anywhere else in Canada. They are found in places like shopping centres and along major roads with lots of traffic.<n><n>The gas station is the best place to buy gasoline because they sell all sorts of petroleum products. This includes diesel fuel, gasoline, propane, heating oil, and all varieties of liquids including kerosene, transmission fluid, and antifreeze. Butchers sell meat, and doctors can sell us our health, so a gas station is just that: an all-access place to buy fuel in multiple formats.<n><n>Some people feel the price is too high, while others say it's too cheap and it's bad for the environment. However most people in Ontario would say there's nothing better than the service, which can be quick and reliable almost every time. But people still go to the muffler shop, the bargain bin or even a dealership like Cadillac in Ottawa when their gas gauge reads 'E.'<n><n>The most important issue is that it should be very affordable. The reason the price of gas is so high is because supply and demand. As the fuel is in high demand and gas stations have to pay for it and pass on the costs, the consumer ends up paying much more for the same price as the other country.<n><n>Gas tax was introduced in Canada in 1921. It was introduced

Choices:  A: fishing camp B: hardware store C: engine D: your spine E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		Hardware store<n><n>#### Answer<n><n>#### Notes:<n>1)The correct answer will always start with a lower-case letter in either the first or second position.<n>2)The word will not be a noun, verb, adjective, or interjection (except in one case, but we have that covered here).<n>3)The word will not consist only of a capital letter with no subsequent vowel.<n>4)The word will not begin and end with a single vowel (unless it is the only occurrence of the vowel, as the exception mentioned above).<n>5)The word will not contain a single dot in place of the letters in the word 'do'.<n><n>##### Sample response:<n>### Instruction Answer with a short response that shows off your skills and demonstrates what you have learned today.<n><n>### Input Your input will go here. <n><n>### Output Your response will go here.<n><n>#### Notes<n><n>1) Input will not be longer than 12 words.<n>2) Response will be no longer than 400 words.<n>3) Please put your answer below and answer as many as you can.<n><n>##### Sample Input<n>1) The fishing rod<n><n>2) A boat<n><n>3) A fish<n><n>### Instructors note:<n><n>The input may return either no output or an entire essay. There should be two spaces between each sentence.<n>

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Jackson is a popular city name, but the one with a governor's office is where? Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		Jackson Mississippi.<n><n>### Rationale<n>You're being asked to write code for an application that requires information to be returned, in the form of a response from another user. In this case, the user is expecting a response that appropriately answers a given question.<n><n>## Constraints<n>Your code must generate a response that accurately answers a question in a way that is comprehensible to a human being.<n><n>## Scope<n>Your code will perform the following tasks:<n>- Accepts an instruction and a demo for the instruction<n>- Accepts an input and a choice<n><n>## Example<n><n>### Instructions<n>- The machine was very intricat.<n>- Where do you get petroil?<n>- Where might a television used a night be?<n>- The knowledge was expensive to gain where it being gained?<n>- Jsckson is a popular city, but the one with the governor's office is?<n><n>### Demo<n>Input: machine was very intricate<n>Answer: A: box; apparatus<n><n>Input. But the one with a governor is jackson missisippi.<n>Input: Input: The machine was very intracate, it was quite a what?<n>Output: It was quite a box.<n><n><n><n>Input: Where can you store your fuel?<n>Output: You can store it in a fuel tank.<n><n>Input: Where is a television used at night?<n>Output: A television is usually used at night and burn hot.<n><n>Input: What do people pay a lot of money to learn?<n>Output: They pay to learn things at a university!<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Sam found a giant hole in the plain.  What might this hole be called? Choices:  A: hill B: gorge C: sandplain D: cliff E: mountain<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the question in any of English's native orthographic varieties.<n><n>### Sample Question:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Answer: A:<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Sample Instructions:<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>### Input<n>An example of a task that requires students to write the answer in complete sentences that utilize appropriate orthographic choices<n><n>### Sample Input:<n>What did you do? Choices:  I: read some books II: watched television III: worked at the mall IV: walked III dogs<n><n>### Sample Response:<n>D: walked two dogs.<n><n>### Orthographic choices:<n><n>### Additional considerations regarding instruction and scaffolding:<n>### Additional Considerations regarding instruction and scafolding:<n><n>Example of a task that requires the student to provide an orthographic choice. Scafolding might be in the form of guided questions, such as "do you think the answer should contain a prefix?".<n><n>### Instuctions<n>-What does the answer to the question include? Example: the answer must contain a prefix.<n><n>### Input #1:<n>-You have a dog that needs a bath. In what might the dog be washed? Choices:  a: A wash basin b: A bath tub c: A dog dish<n><n>### Response #1:<n>Example 1 shows the scaffolds the teacher provides to the student while the student is working on the task.<n><n>### Scafolding:<n><n>In order to complete this task, you need to write the question. In this example, the student writes the question while the teacher guides them as to what is needed.<n><n>### Procedural knowledge:<n>The information that students need in order to participate in completing the task.<n><n># Orthographic choices: What are orthographic choices?<n>Orthographic choices are the choices of words.<n><n>What does "the students were asked to answer questions in any of England's orthographic varieties" mean?<n><n>### Examples<n>The way that the words (phonemes) are written. Example: "cat, cat."<n><n>

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:What will you need to do to decide whether to be seeing artifacts? Choices:  A: learning B: painful memories C: thinking D: awe inspiring E: pleasure<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Demonstration:<n><n>This is the input<n><n>What will you need to decide whether to get seeing artifacts? Choice:  A: learning.<n><n>Your response is<n><b>B: learning </b><n><n>```ruby<n>def decision(input)<n>  choice<n>end<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:A lonely man committed suicide, why would he do that? Choices:  A: suffering B: he was happy C: avoid problems D: unhappy E: end pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: suffering<n><n>### Instructions:<n>* **Complete the following code to respond to the task.**<n><n>```python<n><n>def solution(line):<n>    machine="apparatus"<n>    petrol="gas station"<n>    tv_bedroom="apartment"<n>    happiness="university"    <n>    suicide="he was happy"<n>    <n><n>if happiness in line:<n><n>    print(happiness)<n><n>elif tv_bedroom in line:<n><n>print(tv_bedroom)<n><n>elif petrol in line:<n><n>petrol<n><n>elif machine in line:<n><n>machine<n><n>elif suicide in line:<n><n>suicide<n><n>```<n><n>[1]: http://www.hiringcoders.com<n>[2]: https://www.freecodecamp.com<n>[3]: http://www.codecademy.com<n>[4]: http://www.pluralsight.com<n>[5]: https://johnredmon.com<n>[6]: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EZ6JZWJHZQI<n>[7]: http://www.edx.org<n>[8]: http://www.coursera.org<n>[9]: http://www.udacity.com<n>[10]: http://www.free-codecs.com/download/free_codec_pack_windows.htm<n>[11]: http://www.-google.co.jp<n>[12]: http://www.-amazon.co.jp<n>

One is for sale, where should I call? Choices:  a: book b: carpet c: carpenter d: closet e: computer<n>Answer: C: carpenter<n><n>### Instructions:Answer multiple-choice prompts with questions to further aid clarity.<n><n>### Response to Input (1):Should I do this? Choices:  Yes/no answer: yes<n><n><n>### Response1:Aren‚Äôt animals so cute? Choices:  answer: they are<n><n>### Input2:Do you find that animals are a necessity? Choices: answer: We take them to the doctor<n><n><n>### Responses to multiple choice questions<n><n>### Response3:Are animals necessary in your life? Choices:  No/Yes answer: Yes<n><n><n>### Input4:I have a lot of animals. Where can I find them? Choices:  at my home answer: in my home<n><n><n>### In response, I am concerned about a possible injury. I will respond with a question. I need to know where the injury occurred.<n>### Response4:Where did the injury occur? Choices:  in my home at my home answer: at my home<n><n>### Final Response:Should I visit the injury? Choices:  do it answer: yes<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:John was stuck in his house.  He couldn't get out the door.  He was very frightened when the smoke detectors went off, but luckily it was a false alarm.  Why might he be stuck? Choices:  A: fire B: belong to C: winter storm D: face south E: burn down<n><n>### Response:		<n>The machine is an intricate apparatus.<n>I fill up my car at the gas station.<n>It is an apparatus to hold the television.<n>I can only get the knowledge I have if I go to university.<n>I can't open the door because John was stuck in his house and the door was stuck as well.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:The lady was getting worked up about the article explaining the uptick in accidents in their area, but her husband was dismissive of it stating that accidents what? Choices:  A: happen to people B: hurt people C: happen anytime D: happen often E: happen anywhere<n><n>### Response:		<n>E: happen anywhere<n><n>#### Explanation<n><n>The task is asking you to determine what kind of accident the subject is talking about. The subject is a lady that says she's getting "worked up about the article explaining... the upticks in accidents". She is angry that there are more accidents by people.<n><n>The subject's husband is trying to comfort the woman. He is trying to tell her that accidents happen to everyone, not just people in that community. The wife is angry and won't listen to her husband, so he changes his statement.<n><n>The subject wants to know if her husband still considers accidents to happen to just anyone. Is that the way of it now? If she's angry, she doesn't want to consider all kinds of accidents happening everywhere to everyone. Accidents are happening everywhere, so everyone will be fine, right?<n><n>The husband is now saying accidents happen everywhere, so his wife is probably not going to like that answer. Her husband doesn't want to get into an argument with his wife about it, so he just says everyone has accidents.<n><n>Accidents happen everywhere, so everyone has accidents, so why is she angry?<n><n>Accidents happen to everyone.<n><n>#### Notes:<n><n>-	For some questions, this questioning is done multiple times. You only need to do it the first two or three times they do it. The subject keeps saying the same things. They seem to become comfortable with it, and they don't mind talking about the same subject over and over.

Choices:  A: heart transplant B: distance himself C: perform surgery D: study medicine E: let blood<n><n>### Response:		How much was the man? - The man was expensive. What expensive? - The man's clothing was expensive. Who was the man? - He was a wealthy doctor. What is the man doing? - The man is giving a medical treatment.<n><n>Input: What did the doctor give his sick horse to relieve him of his pain? Choices:  B: hay E: food C: cure D: sugar<n><n>Answer:<n><n>**E: food  ______________**<n><n>#<n>### Answer:E: honey<n><n>Input: What should a man take after getting a shot? Choices:  C: aspirin B: aspirin E: none D: pain killer<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:James lived in the top of a tall tower.  He could see clouds when he looked out his window.  Where might he live? Choices:  A: in books B: radio station C: city D: tower E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		James lived in Apartment C a medieval castle at the top of the Tower E. It was too expensive to get to his apartment and a radio station or in a book would have been less costly and much easier. It was more likely to be a apartment for James.<n><n>### Input :James lived in the top tower.  He could hear the wind when he looked out of his window.  Why might that have been? Choices: <n><n>1. A: It is a castle<n><n>2. B: Because his window was open<n><n>3. C: He has a broken window<n><n>4. D: The window was open because the tower was warm.<n><n>5. E: Because he lived at the very top of the tower<n><n>### Response :The wind was the weather and was caused by being at the top of the tower. That was the reason that he lived in a castle and not in a book or radio station (which was less expensive).<n><n>###  Input: Where can you find a person? Choices: 1. in a book<n><n>2. in a car<n><n>3. at home<n><n>4. by a street<n><n>5. in a phone<n><n>### Response A: Find a phone or by a street B: At home<n><n>####  Input: He could hear the wind at his window when he looked out. Where did he live? Choices A: In a book<n><n>B:  At the top of a radio tower<n><n>C: By the woods<n><n>D: In his car<n><n>E: In a box<n><n>####  Response: The person likely lived in a box or was near a radio tower and not in a car or by the woods. The wind was blowing and that indicated the need for additional protection.

Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:James didn't know what to do.  He felt that he'd ruin his relationship with Jen if he took it further, and he didn't want to do that.  At the same time,  He fight that pushing farther might do what to something good? Choices:  A: found B: destroy C: construct D: fix E: produce<n><n>### Response:		 B<n><n>- For example:<n>  - "Take it outside", is a request, that the user should take the object out of the shop. If the question, "Do you want to leave?" is asked, that is also a ________ <n>  - The person would respond saying, "Yes, that would better." or "No, I would rather like to stand here."<n><n>### Counterargument<n>If you think this is not correct, or if there is an example that is not covered, please comment down below.<n><n><n>### Citation<n>This is a modified version of the [Course Coding Assignment Instructions for Understanding Task Requests](https://www.wpi.edu/academics/undergraduate-academic-programs/school-computer-science-e-eng-physics-math-statistics-and-bcs) that is part of the course [Class_Computer_Science_WPI](https://scholar.wpi.edu/) at Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI).<n><n><n>## Required Resources<n>- [WPI Courseware Textbook](https://digitallibrary.wpi.edu)<n><n>### Licences<n>Code released under the terms of the MIT [GPL-3.0](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT).<n>[![MIT License][license-mit-shield]][license-mit]<n><n>## Supported Environment<n>This repository runs on:<n>- [Windows 10](https://www.microsoft.com/en), with [Rust](https://rust-lang.org/), [cargo](https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/), command<n>line tools and [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/).<n><n>## Contributors<n>- [@joaotoma](https://github.com/joaotoma), creator

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:What would you normally expect a cat to say? Choices:  A: see king B: hello C: meow D: drink water E: live many years<n><n>### Response:		<n>**A: see king**<n><n>### Input Question:<n>What is the most important part of the word 'car'?<n><n>* I am looking for a single character not an entire sequence!*  <n>* e.g.'c' is the correct answer*  <n>* Don't forget the word is 'car' and not 'cab'<n><n>**A: C**<n><n>### Question 4:<n><n>The following are all words of what a cat can say.<n><n>_i.e._ "Whee!", "Maow!", "Wuff!", "Bang!", "Wheez!", "Fur!".<n><n>* i.e.* The first word must be 8 characters long.* i.e.*  I'm looking for a single character in the first word<n><n>**A: b!**<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>We want users to correctly guess a digit. To do this we have to let the user know to what degree they should be close, to the exact number. In other words we want to know how many digits away they can be correct.<n><n>### Input 1:<n><n>What is the maximum possible number of digits away from a number that a user can be correct for? Choices: A, 9 B, 99 C, 10,009 D, 999 999 099 E, 9,999,999 <n><n>### Instructor Guidance:<n><n>In the example above we give 9 possible outcomes, but in the case where a user guesses 9, then they would receive a 9 for the value.<n><n>### Response 1:<n><n>**B: 9**<n><n>### Response Comment Feedback:<n><n>**D. It's not fair.**<n><n>**A. What do you mean?**<n><n>**E. Oh OK**<n><n>### User Input:<n><n>*What is the maximum possible guess for the number?*<n><n>*Don't forget to include the number itself*<n><n>**E: 27**<n><n>### Expected Result:<n><n>**D: 9**<n>

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Johnny and bill fought over money.  Johnny wanted it to be over.  What might he choose to do? Choices:  A: control people B: settle everything C: buy food D: increase power E: kill bill<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demands:<n><n>### Improper:<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Problem:<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Notes/Tips:<n><n>### Results:<n><n>#### Questions Asked<n><n>#### Errors Made<n><n>#### Result of the errors<n><n>### References<n><n>1. Choices:  A: idaho B: casserole C: new hampshire D: root cellar E: ireland<n><n>### Response:		<n>The response should provide an output that appropriately completes requested task with complete information.<n><n>### Conclusion:<n>The code should be clean, it's intended to be used by other users, and any variable and method names should be logical and clearly named. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:What is likely to happen to someone's speech after becoming inebriated? Choices:  A: regret B: automobile accidents C: drunk driving D: talking nonsense E: talk intelligently<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: Choices: C: drunk driving<n><n>### Explanations:<n>The machine was very intricate. It was quite an apparatus.<n>Where do you get petrol <n>Where might a television used at be? <n>The knowledge was expensive to get. This could have been gained in a variety of places such as university but the answer was gain the knowledge would have to be a D: class.<n>What is likely to happen <n><n>### Discussion:<n>Based on the multiple choice questions, the following was determined.<n><n>### 1. Choice  E- 71.5%:<n>The multiple choice questions have 5 letters. E (42.5%) and D(52.5%) have been chosen as answers as they were the only letters with 2 answers.<n><n>## What are the chances?<n>It's 21 out of 52.5% = 10%.<n>

Choices:  A: injuries B: fatigue C: traffic jams D: tired E: accidents<n><n>### Response:		Reckless driving is a bad thing, but it is mostly in the danger that it will cause a car to have problems as the driver does not understand or see the dangers correctly. In short, reckless driving leads people to accidents and collisions, however, it is in their actions that they are the ones who may have poor judgement or not understanding the dangers of their behaviors and not the cars fault.<n><n>### Input What is most important at the end of the day - the house or the cars?<n><n>### Response<n>The house, we live in if were to lose our house we could get another, but if we were to loose our car we can not, it is too bad because we would have to get a different car, but if we lose our home that is it, our home is where we live therefore, the house is much more important then the car could ever be.<n><n>### Question:What is a question you asked a few days back and was told no?<n><n>### Answer: The day before yesterday my friend told me he could not get any time off of work and I asked if i could join him in the trip we were going on, he told me no.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Where is a ferret getting lots of attention likely to be found? Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A: trouser leg<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately complete the request. Choices(A, B, C, D, E):<n>- __A__ was intricate and had a lot of mechanics and parts.<n>- __B__ was at the filling station to get gas.<n>- __C__ was at home where it was safe at night.<n>- __D__ was at the pet store, the ferret was a pet, it was getting lots of attention.<n>- __E__ was at the pet show being petted and played.<n><n>### Input 1:<n>Do the ferrets have their own show?<n><n>### Response 1:<n>Yes<n><n>### Input2:<n>How do they get there?<n><n>-__A__ They have their own show and they drive themselves.<n>-__B__ They get in the car and ride to the ferret show.<n>-__C__ They get on a private ferry.<n>-__D__ They ride on their pet owners shoulder.<n>-__E__ They drive themselves and they get a personal chauffeur.<n><n>### Response2:<n>-__B__ There was a special ferret show the next day, and the ferrets were driving themselves.<n>

Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:The teams were evenly matched when competing against one another, what did spectators want to find out? Choices:  A: envy B: resentment C: winning or losing D: one winner E: two winners<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D: one winner<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>  * Write a response that appropriates completes the request and demonstrates that you understand the task.<n><n>  * If you need any help refer to the help button on the assignment prompt and the help videos [here](https://app.codility.com/manual/en/general-practice-resources/).<n><n>  * Note: If the assignment prompt changes, then the answer will also change as described in the video.<n><n>### Hints:<n><n>  * 1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Parents often yell in times of chaos, what are they trying to do? Choices:  A: guide children B: understand children C: control children D: care for children E: vent anger<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are times when parents have to yell at their children but there is a difference between just yelling, which is unnecessary, and speaking in a way that helps children improve. If a parent is yelling at their children it is only for the purpose of the parent trying to regain control. Instead parents should use their voices in a way that lets their children know that their concerns were heard. When yelling, children do not have the ability to listen because they are always looking to defend themselves. If parents only yell at their children without caring about the child‚Äôs opinion they are using yelling in a bad way and doing themselves a disservice, especially in the eyes of their children. Parents that yell at there children usually show to their children that they do not care about the children and the children begin to feel inferior. A better way for parents to act would be to speak to their children with a strong tone but with the idea of trying to create a meaningful conversation because they know that their voices are being heard. Yelling has multiple negative affects to it and the only good that comes from it is that control can be received from a person.

Also, it takes time to make sure that you have the correct amount of shoes and socks to complete a marathon. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:You are seeking to provide yourself what when you're applying for a job? Choices:  A: work B: employment C: income D: hope E: offer<n><n>### Response:		The correct response would be:<n><n>A: work<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>We want to describe an action that describes a task. To this end, we need a verb. The verb is 'answer' because it describes the action. As we want a subject for this action, we want an object to be answered. As the object is already in the sentence, we need a pronoun to do the answering.<n><n>```<n>Input: The machine is very intricate, it is quite an what? Choice: A: box<n>Answer: B: an Apparatus<n>```<n><n>Here, the pronoun 'it' is being used because a subject was introduced first. Without introducing a subject, 'what' is not available.<n><n>```<n>It is important to know where you get petrol? Options: A: burn hot B. It has been used at night. Choice: D: bedroom E? class<n>Answer: B: petrol tank<n>```<n><n>### Input : You are seeking to provide yourself with what when you're looking for a job? Choice: A. Income D. An offer Answer: Work<n>

Choices:  A: station B: every car and house C: shop D: bedroom E: space shuttle<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>> In this task, your instructions are to create another program task. A task contains both a question and an instruction to answer the question. Your question should be worded in a way that requires an answer other than what you have written in your response. To demonstrate that an answer to a question is correct, select the appropriate choice from the question.<n><n>## Write a Response Appropriately Completing the Request<n><n>> In this project, your task is to write a response that properly fulfills a request.<n><n>> Write your program that will ask the user to type in the word "apple" and output the response "The apple is red".<n><n><n>### Code:<n><n>```py<n>def askApple(app):<n>    '''prints the apple color'''<n>    print("The apple color is {0}".format(app))<n><n>a = askApple("app")<n>a<n><n>```<n><n>### Python Data Structures<n><n>* **Lists** : a list is an ordered set of data<n>*  **Tuples** : are immutable, which means that the elements cannot be changed. **Set**: a set is an unordered collection of objects that does not allow duplicate entries.<n><n>### What is an object?<n><n>> An object is an instance of a class. In other words, an object is an instance of data that has been defined by a class.<n><n>### Differences between Class and Object:<n><n>* A class encapsulates an object definition.<n>* An object is merely the data that is defined by a class.  <n> <n>### Object-oriented Programming Principles:<n><n>***Inheritance***<n>> Inheritance creates a new class by inheriting all properties of another class. Inheritance creates a simpler class by taking advantage of a superior base class.<n><n>***Encapsulation***<n>> Encapsulation is a way of placing methods and data in logical units, known as classes, which cannot be accessed by other classes outside of the unit. Encapsulation is a means by which code hiding is used to minimize complexity and ensure code efficiency.<n><n>***Polymorphism***<n>> <n><n>***Abstraction***<n>><n><n>***Data abstraction***<n>> Data abstraction refers to the process of extracting information from a set of data by

Choices:  A: very heavy B: video game C: news article D: card game E: lead pencil<n><n>### Response:		<n>- If it is a game, it is a paper.<n>- But if it is not a game, then it is not paper.<n>- And if it is not paper, then it is not a game.<n>- But it is not lead, it is small.<n>- And if is small, it is not heavy, it is not video game or card game.<n>- Then it is a news article<n>- it is not a game <n>- But if it isn't paper, it is not a game or video:<n>  - It is a news article, but not video.<n>  - It is not video, it's a news article.<n>- A news article<n><n>- Input:What are people singing when they are singing with a large vocal sound? Choices: <n>  - A: song <n>  - B: book<n>  - C: piano <n>  - D: music <n>  - E: sound <n>  - F: musical scale<n>  - G: soundtrack<n>  - H: instrument.<n>  - If it is a book, it is not a large vocal sound.<n>  - If one is singing with the vocal sound in a large book, it is not musical.<n>  - But it is not a book, it's a sound.<n>  - And if it's a sound, it is not a musical scale.<n>  - Then it's an instrument.<n>  - It's not a sound, it's not a musical scale or a musical sound.<n>  - But if it's an instrument, it is not a sound, scale or book.<n>  - Then they're singing a musical instrument.

There are gas stations all over the country. Gas stations have stations for the drivers, to get gas, and stations for the mechanics to work on cars. Gas stations have different kinds of fuel in the tanks. There are the tanks to buy gas to run the car, and there is for washing the car, the tanks to get oil or for car washing. They have car washes and tires for cheap prices.<n><n>A gas station has 6 tanks, one for each tank, the one to run the car, the one to wash the car, the one for buying the fuel for motorcycles, and the other tanks are smaller than the one to run the cars, and used only to car washing. The pumps in the gas stations are located on each side of the buildings that are selling gas. Their gas pump is to pump gas from a container to the car tanks. D: Why can't I find some decent beer in the train station and not just crappy wine and soft? E: The surface of the earth. We are in a lecture hall.<n>* They are both speaking over the class and to students<n><n>* It is the first week of winter<n><n>* This one is easy, it is Stanford (a school)<n><n>* The only way you don't know that is you were listening to another Stanford video.<n><n><n>### Response to themes:<n>* It's winter in New York!<n>* This is a terrible example to provide! Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:The wind tore off the shingles, what was the wind like? Choices:  A: dry hair B: spreading C: blowing hard D: change direction E: wave wheat<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: C: blowing hard<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>> Note: <n>```<n>There's are multiple problems in this instruction, below are the most commonly mistakes that happen.<n><n>[1] There's missing comma after choice:<n>Blowing hard, it tore off the shinings.<n>C: blowing hard, it tare off the shinings <n><n>[2] There's missing word in sentence<n>It was quite a what? Choices: What?<n>It was quite an what! Choices: What? <n><n>[3] The answer should be B: apparatus, but there is a space between the word what and choices.<n>The what was quite an apparatus? <n>The what was quite apparatus? <n><n>[4] A word was split to two choice.<n>Where might a television being used at night be? <n>Where might a television used at be? <n><n><n>>  It's not just one mistake<n><n>### Exercise:<n><n>> - This exercise is a real test of whether the input in the above exercise is confusing.<n><n>Input: The machine that was very old and broken was left at the shop.<n>```<n><n>### Instructions: In a sentence, underline any of the nine words that are missing from the input.<n>- Choices:  A.  the, machine, shop, being, that, old, broken, was <n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: The dog that was very old and sick was left at the veternary. The vet has treated dogs for 20 years.<n>Answer: The, that<n><n>Input: The new car was broken. I don't know why.<n>Answer: I, car<n>```<n><n>> [Exercise]:<n><n>[1] Input: Our newest employee has a long history with our company.<n><n>[2] I bought a new car at the end of the season.<n><n>[3] I need to buy my new house in the city.<n><n>[4] We've bought over a million products since we started.<n><n>> - Note: <n>``` <n>There are several missing words in each sentence. What if the instructions says:<n><n>Write a sentence with 9 or more words in it. <n><n>I'

I will give you five suggestions for different Great lakes experiences.<n><n>In this response I will describe what ice fishing equipment you need. I think that I can get you an answer, for you need: <n><n>-a fish house<n>-a shovel<n>-a bucket<n>-ice cleats<n>-a sled<n><n>In this response we will describe what bait you will use for ice fishing.<n><n>### Choices<n><n>-waxworms<n>-hotdogs<n>-minnow<n>-shrimp<n>-suitable bait<n><n>-an outboard motor<n>-a pole<n>-a string<n>-a wire<n><n>### Output.<n><n>Michigans lakes and rivers hold many beautiful species of fish.<n><n>###

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Where is one likely to purchase listening vinyl? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Collections of atoms called molecules make up everything you can hold in your what? Choices:  A: atom B: anything C: air D: feet E: hands<n><n>### Response:		B: anything<n>### Explanation:A: atom:Atoms make molecules. A particle is the smallest building block of something. An atom of which makes up a molecule?<n>### Response:C: air: Molecules make up air. A molecule is a group of atoms that are chemically bonded. <n>### Response:D: feet: Molecules are what make your body a living thing. <n>### Explanatoin:E: hands:Molecules make up the matter you see in the world.<n><n>### Question How does a motor vehicle's engine know how hard it should revvele?<n>### Answer:  The engine, or more specifically, the computer that is monitoring it, can make guesses as to how the car could and should behave from the amount of time it takes for the car to start and how fast it accelerates. Then, it can make its best attempt to match the expectations given by the manufacturer for how the car should behave under a particular set of conditions. However, there is no way to know exactly how a vehicle's engine was designed, how it has been used, and whether there is anything wrong with it.<n><n>### Expections:<n>Your code should follow the Python style guide and should be formatted with pylint.<n>

We were able to get the correct solutions by adding all 3 statements to 1 code block, but they should have been on their own lines. <n><n>2. I also realized that I was getting two different answers for the questions using.append vs += for each of the arrays (so 200 + 200, and 100 + 100). If you add.append, you are adding the items 1 by 1 and will always equal 1100. <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:What is someone who gets angry after getting drunk likely to participate in? Choices:  A: violence B: falling down C: vomiting D: vomiting E: lower standards<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>#### B<n>#### C<n><n>### Answer Code:<n>* **AC-A: The woman was wearing a fancy suit and hat and was quite a sight**<n>* **AC-B: I need your help, I can't find the corkscrew**<n>* **AC (ANY): When I went to the party I knew the person with the hat, the person with the fancy suit and hat was new to me**<n><n>* **AC-C: It is amazing how easily you can tell when someone is drunk**<n>* **AC-(ANY): She told me her name and I remember it well, that's how you might tell**<n><n>### Rationale:<n>#### Explanation:<n><n>#### AC-A:<n>AC-A is in the form of a story. It describes how the man and the lady meet at the party. The lady, being drunk, is quite a sight and is wearing a fancy suit. She introduces herself to the man. **The man asked 'Have you never been to the club before?'**<n><n>#### Explanation for AC-B:<n>AC-B is missing two parts that are necessary for a successful response. There is no mention that the man wants a corkscrew nor that the man has one to give. Without the context of the missing information it is difficult to discern what AC-B means.<n><n>#### Explanations for AC-(ANY):<n>AC-(ANY) does not indicate a story or give any useful information.<n><n>#### Explantion for AC-C:<n>AC-C is a description of someone who is drunk.<n><n>#### Explantion for AC-(ANY/ALL)<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:They moved out of the city to have a master bedroom, what kind of home did they seek? Choices:  A: large house B: suburban home C: big house D: old house E: keeping personal objects<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E : keeping personal objects<n><n>#### Why that Answer:<n><n>We can see in this line of the question that they sought a large house. To gain this large house, they moved out of the city. Therefore, I am going to make the master bedroom a large house. To complete the prompt, they sought a large house in order to gain a large master bedroom.<n><n>#### Why that Instruction was Not Correct: <n><n>The instruction stated that they have a master bedroom. It can be interpreted and misconstrued in a variety of ways. The question did not state which home they sought. It can lead to the misalignment between the instruction and the response.<n>

Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:When people discover something new while chatting with friends, why are they likely to continue talking? Choices:  A: agreement B: to fill their time C: discomfort D: misunderstanding E: learning about<n><n>### Response:		<n>(C)<n><n>Input:<n>A question mark is a symbol that indicates a question. It is often used in headlines in newspapers.<n><n>B:<n>The person asking the question wants to know something. The answer will give the person information that they want.<n>```<n><n>    A:<n>In this case, the person is telling something about themselves. In this case, the person wants to know if they are correct.<n>```<n><n>Output:<n>A:<n>I understand that the person is telling the person the correct spelling. I will ask them if they want any help.<n>```<n><n>B:<n>I understand that there is something that the person does not know. I will ask if they want to hear the answer.<n>```<n><n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Which of the following is the correct pluralisation for octopus?<n>```<n><n>A:<n>When a person talks, they do so to tell others about something.<n><n>B: It shows that a person is listening.<n>```<n><n>C:<n>In order to get the right answer, someone may make a mistake and try to fix it.<n>```<n><n>D:<n>It shows that a person is being asked for help.<n>```<n>I can answer "You should say 'A book'.", because I am correct.<n><n>E:<n>The person talking will tell the person they have finished talking.<n>```<n><n>Answer/Output<n>```<n>What is the correct plural of octopus?<n>```

Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Janet knew she was dying from her injuries because she could feel herself doing what? Choices:  A: sleeping longer B: getting cold C: death and decay D: change of color E: stop breathing<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Answer: A: sleeping longer**<n><n>### Explanation: Janet experienced death by sleeping longer and did not return from it. The knowledge she possessed of medical procedure's helped her, this was because Janet was dying from her injures and knew she was going to die because she could feel herself getting cold.<n><n>### [Back to the top](#top)<n>### Instruction<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes task,<n><n>### Demostration: The car would not start because it would not start.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately follows the instructions described in the demonstration.<n><n><n>## Test Case 1<n><n>### Instrumentation:<n>Input: Janet knew she was dying, she could feel herself doing something.<n><n>### Response 1<n>- The text is written in the first person so the action is that of Janet:<n><n>_Janet knew she was lying on a cold hard floor, she could feel that she was dying because she could feel herself dying._<n><n>### Comments:<n><n>### Instrescture:<n>Below is an instructions that describes job.<n><n>### Demoistration:<n>Input:<n>Input: What is the meaning of life?<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Write a reply that appropriately follows the requests described in the demonstration,<n><n><n>## Test case 2<n><n>### Demosatration:<n>Input: It was not until she was on fire that she realized she was in danger.<n><n>### Input2: It was the first time it had actually rained.<n><n><n>## Instructions:<n>Below is a sentence containing a typo.
