This is because he or she is making an assumption that the person is still holding onto the money. This is the only correct answer.<n><n>### Feedback: The person made an assumption.<n><n>### Input and Output Data Example:<n>For the below instruction input, in the response the person did not make any assumptions and they didn't include any additional information.<n><n>### Example Input:<n>Tell if someone is doing good or bad.<n><n>### Response<n>The person asked, what happened to the person? The only assumption the person is making is that the person is happy or unhappy.<n><n>#### Example 2:<n><n>### Input<n>Explain the following statement.<n><n>### Output<n>When the person said, "you mean what did he do?" the response was "not specifically what he did". The response provided a simple explanation as to why the statement didn't make sense. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Which effect of stress could cause death if not treated immediately? Choices:  A: age grieving person B: heart attacks C: depression D: hair loss E: headache<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n>## Instruction:<n><n>Write a response that appropriately complete the request.<n><n>- Create a variable to store an answer to the question<n>- Use the while loop on the variable<n>- Run the loop for 50 steps<n>- Each time it runs the loop, write it to the file<n>    - Using the variable `count`<n>    - Append the variable `count` to the text<n>- Use the print() function to print two variables to the terminal<n>    - `count`<n>    and `(input())`<n>- Use the if statement to add two lines of information to the file<n>    if `count==0`<n>        Write a word about the effect of stress<n>    if `count<0`<n>        print a question and an answer to the terminal<n>- Close the file<n><n><n><n>## Solution<n><n>	import time<n>	import os<n>	filename="test.txt"<n>	count=0<n>	count+=1<n>	countline=count<n>	countline==0<n>	print(countline, file=open(filename), end="-"*70,"line end", sep="-"*30)<n>	print((input()), countline, file=open("test.txt"))<n>	for i in range(50):<n><n>		print(input(), countline, file=file)<n>		countline+=1<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:If one sees a fox and is standing in a coastal, gulf state, where is this person? Choices:  A: alabama B: louisiana C: south carolina D: arkansas E: mountains<n><n>### Response:		B: louisiana<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple question.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Create methods called setAge() and setHeight() such that you may assign a value to those attributes that are declared as variables "this.age" and "this.height"<n><n>#### This class is for your method<n><n>* public height { get; set; }<n>* public age { get; set;<n><n>#### Methods<n><n>* public setAge(number age) { this.age = age; }<n>* public setHeight(height) { 	this.height = height; }<n><n>### Demoscene:<n><n>#### Output:<n><n>input: setHeight(5);<n>this.height<n>5<n><n>####Output:<n><n>input:this.age = 7;<n>this.age<n>

sets a time, the machine is in standby mode<n>                print("Machine is in standby mode")<n>                print("Starting the engine")<n>                start() #starts the machine<n>                response = False<n>                break<n>            elif option.strip() =='burn hot':<n>                print("A:  You have chosen to burn hot

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:They launch a surprise attack, this ended the what? Choices:  A: surrender B: defence C: retreat D: cease fire E: defend<n><n>### Response:		A: surrender<n><n>It is a common mistake to assume that multiple choice questions can be answered in multiple ways, this is not the case. In multiple choice questions when a response does not match with a correct choice, all possibilities are ignored. It is recommended to first try all possible matches before starting to write the complete answer. The answer must match the same as that given in the multiple choice.

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:When someone falls from a mountain it will lead them to? Choices:  A: too much B: act dead C: die D: rush E: explode<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Explain:<n>When a mountain climber falls off a mountian it leads them to certain death because nothing can survive the free fall (in terms of pressure) of the climber hitting the ground.<n><n>#### Demonstration/Answer:<n><n>### Input :When someone is hungry, what is their natural inclination to do? Choices: <n>A: eat B: run C: breathe D: cry E: feel sick<n><n>### Response / Demonstration :<n><n>#### Explain:	<n>One‚Äôs natural inclination when they are hungry is to eat. Their body will produce natural bodily functions in order to survive. To survive it requires them to satisfy their need for sustaion.  It isn‚Äôt healthy to deprive your body of sustanace for a long period of time. This could lead to starvation. <n><n>#### Demonstartion:<n>One of the most important things to do in the event of starving to death is to prepare your body, mind and soul for this. Your body will create a state of starvation which makes you tired and lazy. To prevent this your body will get into an uptempo mood. To prevent starvation you will need to learn how to survive with food and how to prepare it with the tools you can get a hold of.<n>

He felt that the alternative might have results that were too what? Choices:  A: eternal B: religious C: unpredictable D: holy E: monastic<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: D: holy<n><n>### Instructions:<n>If you don't know the answer, guess. <n>Please do not write anything that is not a question.<n>The answers may differ depending on where you live.<n><n>### Other Notes:<n><n>You will learn to write more complex questions as you continue in this assignment.<n><n>### Feedback<n><n>#### A: Burn Hot<n>-<n>An apparatus is an item that's used to do something or achieve a particular result. <n><n>Another word for apparatus is device.<n><n>-<n><n>In this passage we have the word 'apparatus' - an item, an object, used for something.<n><n>-<n>An apparition is a ghostly vision. <n><n>In this sentence the word is referring to apparatus.<n><n>#### B: Fuel Tank<n>-<n>A geyser is a hole through the earth that springs out boiling water or steam, often with much force. <n><n>The water in a geyser can be boiling hot and the steam can be very hot and can cause burns. <n><n>We sometimes use the word tank to refer to a device that holds something that is liquid and is under great pressure.<n><n>-<n>We have a device that's under great pressure to hold something that is liquid. <n><n>This 'device that holds a liquid under great pressure' is a 'tank'. <n><n>The 'tank' is in the 'geyser'. <n><n>The contents of the 'tank' in the 'geyzer' is 'hot water'. <n><n>-<n>When the 'tank' blows out the boiling water, we say that the 'geyser' goes off.<n><n>```<n>A tank on the ground goes off if it's boiling water or steam comes out.<n>```<n>When the 'tanks' that are underground in the volcano go off, they also are called 'geysers'<n>#### C: Burn Hot<n>- <n>A car is a machine that is powered by means of an engine and has at least four wheels. <n><n>A car is a motorcar.<n><n>Burning means causing a fire or something to burn.<n><n>-<n>A car is a device with many moving parts that uses an engine to be moved. <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:What business has a tower to transmit signals? Choices:  A: city B: toronto C: radio station D: roger that E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n>What business has a tower transmit signals? I answer you with a question, what type of radio station is a radio tower used for? It is a transmitter, and we all know radio transmits signals. The answer is:B: toronto, because toronto is a business that has radio transmission towers.<n><n>### Input - What type of building is a business that has a tower? To transmit?<n><n>### Response - I hope I clear it up for you that it is a business.<n><n>### What building is a business that uses tall towers to transfer signals?<n><n>### What business has a tower to broadcast?<n><n>### I hope I am clear enough that it is a business and towers.<n><n>We have a computer, it is our tower. What might the tower that a radio station has do? Is it a cabinet? Can it be an apparatus? Nope. That isn't it...it is a tower where the radio waves transmit.<n><n>So, what might be it. The tower that is owned by the city of Toronto, it is a business, and that is a business that has towers to transmit. So, I hope I made myself clear enough with this question and answer.<n><n>What business has a transmitter and towers that might transmit?<n><n>I hope I made myself clear, that is, a business has a tower to transfer its signals.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:Where would you store a shopping bag if all the seats in your vehicle are full? Choices:  A: the roof B: storage cabinet C: car trunk D: retail store E: home<n><n>### Response:		<n>The shopping bag could be stored in the<n>[house.](https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/house)<n><n>(If you choose this then you must add a closing punctuation mark. If there's no other option it must be one or more period(s)), (but there may not be).<n><n>### Explanation:<n>There's only one possible answer to the question given. (If there is more than one option, you may either select "None of the above" as your answer, or create at least two valid answers.)<n><n>### Additional instructions:<n>If there's no other plausible answer, you may select 'none of the above' as your answer. However, it's important that you don't make un-necessary assumptions about the user's answer. For example, if you don't know whether or not the user would leave a bag in the house if all seats in their vehicle are full, you may not select "house" as option. In this case, you may instead select "None of the Above."<n><n>For this test case, the house is the only option. So there's no need to write a second answer about this particular test case.<n><n>### Constraints:<n>If any of the following constraints are violated, your grade is an E:<n><n>* Do not select "None of the options" as an answer if there is an option that could have been selected. If your are unsure of where to store the bag, your response may not have an option for storing the bag.<n>* Do not select more than one option, if there are more than two distinct options.<n>* Do not write a sentence fragment (a subject without a verb, or a phrase without a noun in it).<n><n>### Good answer:<n>The shopping bags could have been [stored in the house.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House)<n><n>### Bad answer:<n>It can be stored in your car.<n><n>### Notes:<n>* If there is an option that does not fit, write it in. For example, if the options are 'in the car' and 'in the house', then write 'none of the above.'<n>* You may not answer differently. If 'in the house' is the only option and'storing it' is an option

Write a task that is appropriate for the specific time period, event, or location that corresponds with the following timeframe, location, or event.<n><n>### Task Types:<n>Tasks can be categorized into the categories that are listed below. A task in which you spend most of your day doing it, and it is also in an environment where you interact a lot with other people.<n><n>* A normal day which is a daily task that you do each day.<n>* A social task which is where you often interact with other people.<n>* A personal hobby or interest which is a task that you do for fun.<n>* An outdoor activity on a nice day.<n><n>### Timeframe<n><n>Time means when an action/event occurred, or will occur. When you have a long time or a short time to do something you have your choice to decide.<n>We use words like:<n><n>- For a few minutes<n>- In a few minutes<n>- A few days<n>- In a few days<n><n>These can all mean the same amount of time. It is only used when we are talking about a short period of time.<n>We use words that mean a long period of time when we are talking about long periods of time. We say things like:<n><n>- A few years<n>- Ten years<n>- Thirty years<n>- Forty years<n>- Fifty years<n>- Sixty years<n><n>### Event Types:<n>There are many different events that can happen to people in their daily lives. For example, a child might attend a friend‚Äôs birthday party, see a new movie, or take a family vacation.<n>For each of these event types, write a task that is appropriate to the timeframe and event type you have chosen.<n><n>

Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:If you're afraid of spiders what should you avoid owning? Choices:  A: meadow B: cupboard C: shed D: mail box E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A: meadow<n><n>### Instructions for your response:<n>- One sentence only.<n>- Use only the words provided.<n>- Read the sentence below to make sure you understand the task.<n><n>### Example answers:<n>- "If you're afraid from spiders, you should avoid owning" A: meadow = a large area of grassland outside towns or villages.<n>- "If you are afraid from spiders, then you could avoid owning" A = meadow = a large piece of grassy land outside towns or villages usually with woods.<n><n>### Checker:<n>- It says "you should avoid owning"<n>- "If you‚Äôre afraid of spiders then you should avoid owning, the cupboard.<n>- "If You‚Äôre afraid of spider, you should avoid owing"<n><n>### Tip:<n>- Try using the verb "should" in another verb. "If I were you I would avoid owning meadow"<n>- You can also leave the subject out by using an article or personal pronoun. "Me? I would avoid owning a meadow." "If I was you I'd avoid owning a meadows."<n>- You could change the sentence to say it is better to avoid owning a spider. "Spiders are a bad idea to keep".<n>- If you don't agree with the task, you don't have to answer it. :)<n>

Choices:  A: church B: theatre C: large city D: water fountain E: central park<n><n>### Response:		A statue is a model of a human being or animal generally larger than life (not to be confused with a bust). A statue will generally give the human form but may have other focuses. There are statues in different sizes ranging from 10 feet up to hundreds or even thousands of feet. There are statue made out of nearly every material and can be found in every type of environment. The term "statue" applies to any free standing monumental sculpture regardless of time period. (Wikipedia).<n><n>Output: The knowledge was expensive, where was it being bought? Choices: <n>A: library  B: school  C: bookstore  D: college  E: grocery store<n><n>Answer: C: bookstore

"Hang up a sweater." would mean to put away a sweater that wasn't being used, Choice B <n>- The sentence "Why did he hang up the receiver?" leads us to believe what is happening to John, Choice D <n>- The sentence is not clear unless John is doing what, Choice E<n>- John's action fits what meaning of the phrase "it's a turnoff," Choice E<n><n>### Your Response: <n>- John is a what and what? Choices: A: walk B: motor car C: motorbike D: walk  E: taxi<n><n>### **_Response:_*_<n><n>```<n>Reliability:<n><n>* Transport is a mode of moving around from one place to another <n><n>* Means of Transport are vehicles (a thing used for transporting people or objects).<n>* Transport is a system of transferring goods from their production place to the place of consumption.<n><n>```<n><n>| Transport         |Means of Transport|                   Definition|                  <n>|:----------------:|:----------------:|------------------------------:|:-:|<n>|Transportation    |Vehicles          |Transferring of people or goods  |<n><n>| Transportation     |Means of Transport  |                               Definition|:-:|<n><n>|Transportation      |Vehicles      |Transporting of people or goods        |        <n><n>- The most reliable methods of transport are *walk*, *bike*, and *taxi* because these modes can easily go into places and places where no cars can pass.<n><n><n>##  Input :I like to stay at the home I own on the farm.It is convenient to own<n><n><n>##  A. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:If people listen, they can understand each other better.  If they understand each other, they can do what? Choices:  A: pay bills B: swap bodies C: learn from each other D: believe in god E: talk to each other<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>> B: swap bodies<n><n><n><n><script><n>    /*<n>     * Test.js<n>     */<n><n>  /**<n>   * @this {Element} DOM node of the task box<n>   * @constructs Test<n>   * @return {Test}<n>   */<n>  function SampleConstructor() {<n><n>  }<n><n>/**<n> * Return the correct answer<n> *<n> * @param {Object} answer - The selected answer from a user<n> * @return {*} - The best available answer<n> * @throws TypeError - When the answer is undefined or not valid.<n> */<n>Test.prototype.doAnswer = function(answer) {<n>  if (typeof ( answer ) === 'undefined' || typeof ( answer )!='string') {<n>    throw new TypeError('The answer must be a string');<n>  }<n><n>  // Test answer against the correct answer<n>  if (answer.toUpperCase() === this.answer) {<n>    return true;<n>  } else {<n>    this.answer = answer;<n>    return false;<n>  }<n>};<n><n>Test.prototype.check = function() {<n>  // if a user chooses answer "B"<n>  // we want to return the value "B"<n>  this.doAnswer('B');<n><n>  // if a chooses answer "X"<n>  // we check if the answer is valid or not<n>  console.log(this.answer);<n>};<n><n><n>this.constructor();<n></script><n><n><link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css"><n><link rel="shortcut icon" href="favicon.ico"><n><link rel='stylesheet' href='styles.css'><n><n><title>Multiple Choice</title><n>

A lot of the common English expressions used here aren‚Äôt common in other cultures/languages. So even for those problems that seem like they‚Äôre about English grammatical, you have to think about what the appropriate expression is for that language. <n>* In general it makes sense that a lot of the test-taker issues relate to just simple test-taking issues (know the question, make sure you understand the prompt, etc).<n>

Choices:  A. focus<n>D. listen carefully<n>B. take notes<n>C. gain experience<n>E. complete test<n><n>#### A student wants to hear (focus) what (topic) what (topic, too) the professor (teach).<n><n>### Excellent response:<n>The professor was explaining the quadratic formula.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>Input: Where might a television used at night be? Choices:  A: cabinet B: house C: apartment D: bedroom E: woods<n>Answer: D: bedroom<n><n>Input: The knowledge was expensive to get, where was it being gained? Choices:  A: university B: book C: field D: meeting E: class<n>Answer: A: university<n><n>### Input:After bringing eggs home from the store in what are they held? Choices:  A: chicken coop B: supermarket C: box D: egg carton E: henhouse<n><n>### Response:		Chicken coop<n><n>Here is the code<n>```swift<n>//Code<n>var correctAnswers = 0<n><n>(questions.question) <n><n>if (answers.isCorrect) {<n>correctAnswers += 1<n>answer = true<n>print("Correct answer")<n><n>}<n><n><n>if (answres.isWrong) {<n>    answer=false<n>    print("Wrong Answer")<n><n>}<n>//Display the correct and wrong answers to the user<n>print("You got \(correctAnswers) out of \(questions.questions.count) correct answers")<n><n>//Print answer after the user presses enter<n>print("Do you want another challenge? (y/n)")<n>let answer = String(input:StdIn.readLine())<n><n>if (answer=="y") {<n>print("Great!")<n>let questions = Questions(question:[<n>    Question(question:"What is the box to the TV called?",answers: [<n>        Answer(isCorrect:false,isWrong:false, answer: "box")<n>        Answer(isWrong:true, isCorrect:false, answer: false, "implement")<n>        Answer(false,isCorrect:false,"TV stand")<n>        Answer(correct:true,isWrong:true,"apparatus")<n>        Answer(true,"TV stand")<n><n>    ]),<n>    Question(question: "Where do you get gasoline for your car?",Answers: [<n>        [true,"burn hot"), [true, "burn hot"), [false,"gas station"],<n>        [false,"burn hot"), [false, "car"]<n>    ]),<n>    <n>    Question(question : "Where will you find a television at night?",Answers:[<n>        [true, "bedroom"], [false, "Apartment"], [false, "house"], [true, "house"]<n>    ]), <n>    <n>    Question (question: "Where is the knowledge gained?",Answers :[<n>        [false, "class"], [false, "university"], [true, "university"],<n>        [true, university"], [false, "book"], [true, "book"], [false, "field"],<n>        [true,"class"], [false, house"],<n>    ]),  ]

Choices:  A: relax B: controversy C: pleasure D: frustration E: needs theater<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: A what B: an what C: a what D: what<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Below is an instruction that describes an action. <n>Write a request that appropriately completes this action.<n><n>### Input requesting an action:Put your pants on.<n>### Solution:<n>Pants is __ing. Put is a verb. Pants __ a verb. Pants on is an action phrase. Therefore, the solution is Put is on.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Instuction:<n>Below is a description of a task. Write a request that appropriately begins the task.<n><n>### Description of task:<n>Put a coat on, it's cold.<n><n>### Request:<n>The correct request is Put a what on a cold day.<n><n>### Solution: Put is a verb, coat on is an action phrase, so it can be answered with Put a what on a what.<n><n>### Response <n><n>Put a what on a what<n><n>### Request<n><n>### Solution<n><n><n><n># What is English grammar?<n><n>* Grammar is a set of rules that define what is good writing and what is okay or poor writing.<n>* Grammar tells us things to avoid and things that are more pleasing to read (i.e. good writing).<n>* Grammar defines whether a sentence is being used at its best to convey something.<n><n>### Example:<n>There are an ___ dog.<n><n>### Answers:<n><n><n><n>### <n>### Description:<n>The sentence is incomplete. It needs an ___ dog to have a complete sentence.<n><n>###
